hints_html:
The formula for the centre of mass of a continuous distribution over the interval \(0\leq x\leq L\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x}=\frac{\int_{0}^{L}x\rho (x)dx}{\int_{0}^{L}\rho (x)dx}\end{aligned}\]

where \(\rho(x)\) is the mass density function.
hints_raw:
The formula for the centre of mass of a continuous distribution over the interval <math>0\leq x\leq L</math> is

:<math>
\overline{x}=\frac{\int_{0}^{L}x\rho (x)dx}{\int_{0}^{L}\rho (x)dx}
</math>

where <math>\rho(x)</math> is the mass density function.
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
Given the mass density function \(d(x)=4-x^{2}\) over the interval \(0\leq x \leq 2\), we use the formula for the centre of mass to get

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x} &= \frac{\int_{0}^{L}x\rho (x)dx}{\int_{0}^{L}\rho (x)dx} \\ &= \frac{\int_{0}^{2}x(4-x^{2})dx}{\int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx} \\ &= \frac{\int_{0}^{2}(4x-x^{3})dx}{\int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx} \\ &= \frac{I_1}{I_2}\end{aligned}\]

The integral on the top is calculated as

\[\begin{aligned} I_1 &= \int_{0}^{2}(4x-x^{3})dx \\ &= \left [2x^{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{4} \right ]_{0}^{2} \\ &= \left [\left ( 2(2)^{2}-\frac{(2)^{4}}{4} \right )- \left ( 2(0)^{2}-\frac{(0)^{4}}{4} \right ) \right ] \\ &= 4\end{aligned}\]

and the integral on the bottom reduces to

\[\begin{aligned} I_2 &= \int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx \\ &= \left [4x-\frac{x^{3}}{3} \right ]_{0}^{2} \\ &= \left [\left ( 4(2)-\frac{(2)^{3}}{3} \right ) - \left (4(0)-\frac{(0)^{3}}{3} \right ) \right ] \\ &= \frac{16}{3}\end{aligned}\]

Putting these together we finally obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x} = \frac{I_1}{I_2} = \frac{4}{\frac{16}{3}} = \frac34\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, the correct answer is (iv).
sols_raw:
Given the mass density function <math>d(x)=4-x^{2}</math> over the interval <math>0\leq x \leq 2</math>, we use the formula for the centre of mass to get

:<math> \begin{align}
\overline{x} &= \frac{\int_{0}^{L}x\rho (x)dx}{\int_{0}^{L}\rho (x)dx} \\
&= \frac{\int_{0}^{2}x(4-x^{2})dx}{\int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx} \\
&= \frac{\int_{0}^{2}(4x-x^{3})dx}{\int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx} \\
&= \frac{I_1}{I_2}
\end{align}</math>

The integral on the top is calculated as

:<math> \begin{align}
I_1 &= \int_{0}^{2}(4x-x^{3})dx \\
&= \left [2x^{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{4}  \right ]_{0}^{2} \\
&= \left [\left ( 2(2)^{2}-\frac{(2)^{4}}{4} \right )- \left ( 2(0)^{2}-\frac{(0)^{4}}{4} \right )  \right ] \\
&= 4
\end{align}</math>

and the integral on the bottom reduces to
:<math> \begin{align}
I_2 &= \int_{0}^{2}(4-x^{2})dx \\
&= \left [4x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}  \right ]_{0}^{2} \\
&= \left [\left ( 4(2)-\frac{(2)^{3}}{3} \right ) - \left (4(0)-\frac{(0)^{3}}{3} \right ) \right ] \\
&= \frac{16}{3}
\end{align}</math>

Putting these together we finally obtain
:<math>
\overline{x} = \frac{I_1}{I_2} = \frac{4}{\frac{16}{3}} = \frac34
</math>


Therefore, the correct answer is  (iv).
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Select ONE correct answer (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), or (v).

(e) Consider the mass density function

\[\begin{aligned} d(x) = 4-x^2\end{aligned}\]

over the interval \(0 \leq x \leq 2\). The centre of mass of this mass distribution is

(i)   \(\displaystyle {} 1\)    

(ii)   \(\displaystyle {} 4\)    

(iii)   \(\displaystyle {} \frac43\)    

(iv)   \(\displaystyle {} \frac34\)    

(v)   \(\displaystyle {} \frac{16}3\)
statement_latex:
Multiple Choice Question: Select \textbf{ONE} correct answer \emph{(i)},
\emph{(ii)}, \emph{(iii)}, \emph{(iv)}, or \emph{(v)}.

\textbf{(e)} Consider the mass density function

\begin{align*}
d(x) = 4-x^2
\end{align*} over the interval $0 \leq x \leq 2$. The centre of mass
of this mass distribution is

\emph{(i)} ~ $\displaystyle {} 1$ ~ ~

\emph{(ii)} ~ $\displaystyle {} 4$ ~ ~

\emph{(iii)} ~ $\displaystyle {} \frac43$ ~ ~

\emph{(iv)} ~ $\displaystyle {} \frac34$ ~ ~

\emph{(v)} ~ $\displaystyle {} \frac{16}3$
